Animation.Name: Hammer Thrower Comparison
Animation.Description: Illustrates how the movement of a star and its planet about their center of mass compares to a hammer thrower swinging a heavy metal ball.

Animation.Name: Eclipsing Binary Simulator
Animation.Description: Models the motions of two stars in orbit around each other, and the combined lightcurve they produce. This simulator allows the user to control multiple parameters to see how they effect the lightcurve. Includes several real datasets.

Animation.Name: Gravity Algebra
Animation.Description: Shows how the force of gravity would be different if the values used in Newton's law of universal gravitation formula are changed.

Animation.Name: Lightcurve Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows how a lightcurve is constructed from observations of an eclipsing binary system.

Animation.Name: Center of Mass Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows how the center of mass of two objects changes as their masses change.

Animation.Name: Solar System Properties Explorer
Animation.Description: Allows one to explore a set of histograms for characteristics like number of satellites, mass, orbital period, etc. for the terrestial and jovian planets, plus Pluto.

Animation.Name: Planet Formation Temperatures Plot
Animation.Description: Shows planet formation temperature as a function of distance from the Sun. Also indicates the state (gas or solid) of several substances at the given distance and temperature.

Animation.Name: Daylight Simulator
Animation.Description: Simulation showing daylight and nighttime regions on a flat map of Earth. Daily and yearly motions of the sunlight pattern can be shown.

Animation.Name: Celestial and Horizon Systems Comparison
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how the celestial sphere and horizon diagram are related.

Animation.Name: Sidereal Time and Hour Angle Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Shows how sidereal time and the hour angle of a star are related.

Animation.Name: Small-Angle Approximation Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Shows how small angles can be approximated.

Animation.Name: Big Dipper Clock
Animation.Description: Shows how stars rotate around the North Star over time (both daily and seasonal motions are shown).

Animation.Name: Heliacal Rising Simulator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how the day of the year when a star is first visible in the morning (the heliacal rising) depends on the observer's latitude and the star's position on the celestial sphere.

Animation.Name: Aliasing in Wagon Wheels
Animation.Description: Demonstrates aliasing through the analogy of a wagon wheel being filmed. For some combinations of frame rates and true rotation speeds the wheel can appear to rotate backwards.

Animation.Name: Daylight Hours Explorer
Animation.Description: Shows the hours of daylight received during the year for an observer at a given latitude. This is an important factor contributing to the seasons.

Animation.Name: Meridional Altitude Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows the geometry for calculating the meridional altitude of objects.

Animation.Name: Declination Ranges Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows how an observer's latitude determines the circumpolar, rise and set, and never rise regions in the sky.

Animation.Name: Ecliptic Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows how the sun's declination and right ascension change over the course of a year.

Animation.Name: Union Seasons Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the changing declination of the sun with a time-lapse movie, which shows how the shadow of a building changes over the course of a year.

Animation.Name: Azimuth/Altitude Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the horizon coordinate system, where altitude and azimuth define an object's position in the sky.

Animation.Name: Obliquity Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows how obliquity (tilt) is defined.

Animation.Name: Ecliptic (Zodiac) Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows the sun's position in the sky relative to the background stars (the zodiac constellations) over the course of a year.

Animation.Name: Longitude/Latitude Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates latitude and longitude with an interactive globe, providing an analogy to the celestial and horizon coordinate systems.

Animation.Name: Celestial-Equatorial (RA/Dec) Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the celestial-equatorial (RA/dec) coordinate system, where declination and right ascension define an object's position on the celestial sphere.

Animation.Name: Paths of the Sun
Animation.Description: Shows how the declination of the sun varies over the course of a year using a horizon diagram.

Animation.Name: Sun Motions Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Models the motions of the sun in the sky using a horizon diagram, demonstrating daily and seasonal changes in the sun's position.

Animation.Name: Sun's Rays Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows how the sun's most direct rays hit different parts of the earth as the seasons change.

Animation.Name: Sun's Position on Horizon
Animation.Description: Shows how the direction of the sun at sunrise or sunset changes over the course of the year.

Animation.Name: Big Dipper 3D
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how the stars of the big dipper, which are at various distance from earth, project onto the celestial sphere to give the familiar asterism.

Animation.Name: Seasons Simulator (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Shows the geometry of the earth and sun over the course of a year, demonstrating how seasons occur. This simulator allows both orbital and celestial sphere representations of the seasonal motions.

Animation.Name: Coordinate Systems Comparison
Animation.Description: Shows how the rotation of the earth leads to the apparent rotation of the sky, and how celestial sphere and horizon diagram representations of the sky are correlated.

Animation.Name: Balloon Universe
Animation.Description: An animation of coins attached to a balloon, providing an analogy to the expansion of the universe. The coins represent galaxies, which maintain their scale while the space between them grows.

Animation.Name: Radial Velocity Graph
Animation.Description: Shows a star and planet in orbit around each other while tracing out the star's radial velocity curve.

Animation.Name: Influence of Planets on the Sun
Animation.Description: Shows the movement of the sun due to the gravitational pull of the planets. The contribution from each planet can be isolated by toggling checkboxes.

Animation.Name: Pulsar Period Simulator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how the movement of a pulsar and planet around their common center of mass affects the timing of pulse arrivals.

Animation.Name: ExtraSolar Planet Radial Velocity Demonstrator
Animation.Description: ExtraSolar Planet Radial Velocity Demonstrator

Animation.Name: Transit Simulator (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how a planet passing in front of its parent star can cause dips in the star's lightcurve, potentially leading to the planet's detection.

Animation.Name: Radial Velocity Simulator (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Models the motion of an extrasolar planet and its star around their common center of mass, and the effect this motion has on the star's observed radial velocity.

Animation.Name: Lookback Time Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows how the finite speed of light and the great distances to most astronomical objects cause us to observe things as they were in the past.

Animation.Name: Blackbody Curves of Melting
Animation.Description: A movie showing the heating and eventual melting of a nail, and the theoretical blackbody curve produced in the process.

Animation.Name: Spectrum Explorer
Animation.Description: Allows one to generate a variety of simulated spectra, depending on factors such as the type of source, luminosity class, spectral type, and individually selected elements.

Animation.Name: EM Spectrum Module
Animation.Description: Surveys the electromagnetic spectrum, showing a typical astronomical image for different wavelengths of light and the kind of instrument that would take such an image.

Animation.Name: Blackbody Curves (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how the blackbody spectrum varies with temperature. This explorer also shows how the relative intensities observed through different filters (a 'color index') can give an estimate of temperature.

Animation.Name: Doppler Shift Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Shows circular waves expanding from a source. Movement of the source or observer affects the frequency of the waves seen by the observer, demonstrating doppler shift.

Animation.Name: Filters Simulator (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how different light sources and filters combine to determine an observed spectrum. This simulator also shows the perceived colors associated with the spectra shown.

Animation.Name: Hydrogen Atom Simulator (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Models a hydrogen atom and its interactions with light, demonstrating the quantum nature of absorption and emission.

Animation.Name: Extrasolar Planet Radial Velocity Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how the spectrum of a star is shifted as it and its planet orbit their common center of mass.

Animation.Name: Three Views Spectrum Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how different spectra can arise from a light bulb (a thermal source) and a cold, thin gas cloud. The spectrometer shows emission, absorption, or continuous spectra based on where the draggable telescope is pointed.

Animation.Name: Basketball Phases Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows an illuminated basketball that can be viewed from multiple directions, providing an analogy to moon phases.

Animation.Name: Eclipse Table
Animation.Description: Consists of a table of solar and lunar eclipses, showing the banding that represents the eclipse seasons that occur about twice a year.

Animation.Name: Full Moon Declination Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows the declination range of the full moon over the course of a year, and the corresponding changes in altitude for a northern hemisphere observer.

Animation.Name: Lunar Phases Simulator (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the correspondence between the moon's position in its orbit, its phase, and its position in an observer's sky at different times of day.

Animation.Name: Lunar Phase Vocabulary
Animation.Description: Shows the appearance of the moon at each of the named moon phases.

Animation.Name: Moon Inclination
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how the inclination of the moon's orbit precludes eclipses most of the time, leading to distinct eclipse seasons.

Animation.Name: Three Views Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows how the phase of the moon depends on the viewing geometry by allowing the moon to be viewed from the earth, the sun, and an arbitrary point in space.

Animation.Name: Phase Positions Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how planet and moon phases depend on orbital geometry. Users can drag two bodies around to see how the observed appearances change.

Animation.Name: Moon Phases and the Horizon Diagram
Animation.Description: Provides a method of learning the correlation between the phase of the moon, the time of day, and the position of the moon in the sky.

Animation.Name: Eclipse Shadow Simulator
Animation.Description: Provides draggable earth and moon discs with shadows, which can be used to demonstrate how the umbral (complete) and penumbral (partial) shadows give rise to different types of eclipses.

Animation.Name: Synodic Lag
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the difference between a sidereal and synodic (solar) day, which arises from the earth's revolution around the sun.

Animation.Name: Tidal Bulge Simulation
Animation.Description: Shows how the sun, moon, and earth's rotation combine to create tides.

Animation.Name: Milky Way Rotational Velocity
Animation.Description: A plot of the rotational velocity of stars at varying distances from the center of the milky way. A draggable cursor allows determining the contained mass implied by the curve.

Animation.Name: Traffic Density Analogy
Animation.Description: The build-up of traffic behind a slow moving tractor provides an analogy to the density wave formation of spiral arms.

Animation.Name: Phases of Venus
Animation.Description: Shows what Venus looks like through a telescope as the planets go around in their orbits. Compare with the Ptolemaic Phases of Venus simulation.

Animation.Name: Ptolemaic Phases of Venus
Animation.Description: Shows what Venus would look like through a telescope if Ptolemy's model was correct. Compare with the other Phases of Venus simulation.

Animation.Name: Ptolemaic Orbit of Mars
Animation.Description: Shows Ptolemy's model for the orbit of Mars.

Animation.Name: Epicycles Demo
Animation.Description: Demonstrates that the heliocentric and geocentric models are equivalent for predictive purposes when limited to circular orbits. One can watch the same system in motion with different bodies held in fixed position.

Animation.Name: Retrograde Motion
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the retrograde motion of Mars with an annotated animation.

Animation.Name: Kepler's Third Law
Animation.Description: Lets one calculate the period of a planet from its semimajor axis, and vice versa.

Animation.Name: Synodic Period Calculator
Animation.Description: Lets one calculate the sidereal period of the planet (P) from the synodic period (S), and vice versa.

Animation.Name: Planetary Configurations Simulator (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Models the movements of the planets around the sun in a simplified Copernican model of the solar system.

Animation.Name: Planetary Orbit Simulator (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Models the motion of a hypothetical planet that orbits the sun according to Kepler's laws of motion. This simulator includes controls for investigating each of Kepler's laws.

Animation.Name: Eccentricity Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the parameters that define the eccentricity of an ellipse.

Animation.Name: Distance Modulus Explorer
Animation.Description: Shows how the distance modulus formula combines apparent and absolute magnitudes to give the distance to a star.

Animation.Name: Stellar Velocity Calculator
Animation.Description: Shows how the distance to a star, its doppler shift, and its proper motion allow one to calculate the star's true space velocity.

Animation.Name: Parallax Calculator
Animation.Description: Diagrams the geometry and shows the math involved in determining a star's distance via parallax.

Animation.Name: Spectroscopic Parallax Simulator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how the technique of spectroscopic parallax works. Spectral type and luminosity class determine the observed spectrum of a star, from which the star's luminosity can be estimated.

Animation.Name: Stellar Luminosity Calculator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates how a star's luminosity depends on its temperature and radius.

Animation.Name: Flux Simulator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the inverse square law of light with a lightbulb and detector. The lightbulb's intensity and the detector's distance can be adjusted to see how they affect the reading. There are two bulbs and detectors to allow side-by-side comparisons.

Animation.Name: HR Explorer (NAAP)
Animation.Description: Introduces the Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram, a plot showing the relationship between luminosity and temperature for stars.

Animation.Name: Proton-Proton Animation
Animation.Description: Shows an animated diagram of the proton-proton chain reaction, which is the dominant fusion reaction in the sun's core.

Animation.Name: CNO Cycle Animation
Animation.Description: Shows an animated diagram of the CNO cycle, which dominates in stars larger than the sun.

Animation.Name: Telescope Simulator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the properties of a telescope, and how these vary with aperture and eyepiece selection.

Animation.Name: CCD Simulator
Animation.Description: Shows a rainfall and bucket analogy to CCD imaging.

Animation.Name: Driving Through Snow
Animation.Description: Shows a snow shower from the perspective of a car driving through it, demonstrating how the snow seems to diverge from some central point (the radiant). Provides an analogy to a meteor shower.

Animation.Name: Antipodes Explorer
Animation.Description: Demonstrates antipodal points, which are points on opposite sides of the Earth from each other.

Animation.Name: Sun Motions Overview
Animation.Description: Shows the paths of the sun on the celestial sphere.

Animation.Name: Newton's Law of Gravity Calculator
Animation.Description: Allows one to calculate the force of gravity acting on a variety of masses over a range of distances.

Animation.Name: Earth Orbit Plot
Animation.Description: Shows the orbital period as a function of orbital distance for satellites of Earth.

Animation.Name: Lunar Phase Quizzer
Animation.Description: Shows the standard orbital view of the Moon, but with the option to hide the Moon's phase, the Moon's position, or the Sun's direction.

Animation.Name: Snell's Law Demonstrator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates Snell's Law, a formula that describes how light is refracted when it moves between different media.

Animation.Name: Galactic Redshift Simulator
Animation.Description: Demonstrates the redshift of a galaxy due to the expansion of the universe, and the effect this shift has on the galaxy's brightness as observed through various filters.

Animation.Name: Moon Phases With Bisectors
Animation.Description: Demonstrates a method for determining moon phases using planes that bisect the earth and moon.

Animation.Name: Sidereal and Solar Time Simulator
Animation.Description: Helps demonstrate the difference between sidereal and solar time.
